title: Massachusetts Leadership Comparison: Baker vs Healey Administrations

overview.purpose: Historical comparison showing how Massachusetts has changed between administrations and connecting policy decisions to outcomes

baker.name: Charlie Baker
baker.approvalRating: Among highest of any US governor throughout tenure
baker.reelection2018: Won with 67% of vote - largest margin since 1994

healey.newTaxes: 4% surtax on income above $1 million (Fair Share Amendment)

stabilizationFund.description: Massachusetts 'Rainy Day Fund' - reserve for fiscal emergencies

baker.keyQuote: We are able to responsibly grow our reserves without raising taxes

baker.approach: Began converting hotels to temporary housing as migrant numbers rose in late 2022
baker.spending: System was manageable; no state of emergency declared
baker.note: Crisis began ramping up at end of Baker term

healey.auditFindings: State Auditor found 'improper and unlawful' no-bid contracts
specificWaste: $140 cab fare for 223-foot parking lot ride
$10 million no-bid contract with caterer lasting 8 months
healey.healeyResponse: Rejected audit findings; said 'I doubt' changes needed

shelterSystem.accountability: Healey administration made decision to declare emergency and award no-bid contracts

mbta.context: Boston's public transit system - chronic problems spanning both administrations

issues: FTA issued scathing safety report in 2022
Orange Line shut down for month in 2022
Train caught fire on bridge - passenger jumped into river
Service cuts due to staffing shortages
baker.ftaFinding: Still recovering from funding cuts made in 2015-2019 which resulted in reduction of hundreds of millions of dollars and hundreds of positions
baker.investments: Spent $2 billion on capital projects in FY2022, up from $875 million in FY2018
baker.greenLineExtension: $2.3 billion project - later found to have defective tracks

actions: Appointed Phil Eng as General Manager (April 2023)
Eliminated all slow zones by December 2024 - first time in 20 years
healey.improvements: Travel times shortened: 20+ min on Orange Line, nearly 1 hour on Red Line
ongoingIssues: Operating budget deficit estimated at $700+ million annually
Infrastructure maintenance deficit at least $3 billion annually
Green Line Extension tracks found to be defective - knew since April 2021 but opened anyway
healey.healeyQuote: I took this job understanding that the T was going to be a major, major issue... years of mismanagement and underinvestment

mbta.sharedAccountability: Problems span both administrations - Baker cut funding early in term, Healey inherited mess but slow zones now fixed

outmigration.trend: Massachusetts consistently losing residents to other states

latestData.worseThanStates: Only NY, NJ, IL, CA lost more

whoPeopleLeavingFor.commonFactor: Both have no state income tax

economicImpact.highEarnerShare: 55% of income leaving is from those making $200k+

outmigration.concerningTrend: Young adults ages 25-34 leaving at highest rates - these are economic drivers who buy homes and start families

energyCosts.context: Massachusetts has 3rd highest electricity rates in nation

bakerApproach.2021: Signed climate roadmap requiring net-zero by 2050
bakerApproach.stance: Supported clean energy but opposed millionaire's tax

healeyApproach.2024legislation: Signed 'An Act Promoting a Clean Energy Grid' (November 2024)

delays.cleanHeatStandard: Quietly delayed from 2026 to 2028 in December 2025
delays.reason: Affordability concerns - political cost before reelection

healeyApproach.contradiction: Campaigns as 'climate governor' but delays climate policies when costs become politically inconvenient

keyContrasts.baker: Grew rainy day fund from $1.1B to $8.4B without raising taxes
keyContrasts.healey: Relies on $2.98B millionaire tax; shelter crisis cost $1B+/year

keyContrasts.baker: No major state of emergency declarations beyond COVID
keyContrasts.healey: Declared shelter emergency; audit found 'unlawful' no-bid contracts

keyContrasts.baker: Vetoed $7.9M in FY2022 spending; signed most budget provisions
keyContrasts.healey: Rejected State Auditor findings; 'I doubt' changes needed
Implemented millionaire's tax; energy costs still rising
33,340 net loss in 2025; trend worsening again

quotes.quote: This budget is in balance, does not rely on new taxes, and forecasts a $1.2 billion deposit in the Commonwealth's Stabilization Fund.
quotes.speaker: Charlie Baker

quotes.quote: The Stabilization Fund grew by $7.3 billion since Baker came into office in 2015.
I doubt it. This has been territory pretty well covered.
quotes.speaker: Maura Healey
quotes.context: When asked if changes needed based on shelter audit

quotes.quote: The middle class is carrying this state on its back, and getting nothing in return.
quotes.speaker: Mike Kennealy

quotes.quote: Maura Healey completely mismanaged the migrant crisis, wasting hundreds of millions of taxpayers' hard earned dollars on bloated no-bid contracts.
quotes.speaker: Mike Kennealy

quotes.quote: The top driving factors behind domestic outmigration from Massachusetts are taxes, housing costs, and health care expenses.
quotes.speaker: Mark Williams

bottomLine.summary: Under Baker, Massachusetts built fiscal reserves without raising taxes. Under Healey, the state imposed new taxes, spent over $1 billion annually on a shelter crisis marked by 'unlawful' contracts, and continues losing residents to lower-tax states while energy costs remain among the highest in the nation.
bottomLine.voterQuestion: Are current leaders making decisions that benefit Massachusetts residents, or decisions that benefit their political priorities?
